note.p: Charles Clark served as Mississippi’s governor during the last two years of the Civil War. Born in Cincinnati, Ohio, on May 24, 1811, Clark later moved to Mississippi, where he became a lawyer and a state representative in the late 1830s. After successfully representing a Mississippi settler in a land dispute with members of the Choctaw Nation in the early 1840s, Clark received a large tract of land near Beulah, Mississippi, as payment. Clark eventually enlarged his property to over five thousand acres, making it one of the largest and most successful plantations in Mississippi. During this time, he married Ann Eliza Darden and between 1840 and 1852 fathered three children.

Clark volunteered for military service during the Mexican-American War in 1846 and raised a company of volunteers that was placed into the 2nd Mississippi Regiment. After its original commander resigned, Clark was elected colonel. Following the war in 1848, he returned to Mississippi resumed an interest in politics. He was selected as a delegate to a state convention in 1851 that debated the matter of secession in the wake of the Compromise of 1850, which had tried to settle a fierce dispute over the fate of slavery in territories gained by the United States from Mexico. Clark attended the convention as a Unionist, opposed to withdrawing from the Union. Developments over the next ten years changed his mind.

Clark won a seat in the Mississippi’s House of Representatives as a Whig, serving from 1856 to 1861. Following Abraham Lincoln’s election as president in 1860, Clark embraced Mississippi’s secession. When the Civil War broke out, Clark received a commission as a brigadier general in the Mississippi Militia. He later entered the Confederate Army and eventually took command of a division. Slightly wounded at the Battle of Shiloh in April 1862, he was more seriously wounded and captured during fighting at Baton Rouge, Louisiana, in August 1862. Clark spent a short time as a prisoner of war before he was paroled by Union forces.

In 1863, Clark ran for governor of Mississippi, in the wake of Confederate defeats at Vicksburg and Jackson. Clark campaigned on continued resistance to the Union and easily won the executive seat. Due to Union campaigns in Mississippi, Clark periodically moved the state government, from Jackson to Macon, then to Columbus, and back to Macon. When Confederate forces in Mississippi surrendered in May 1865, Clark instructed the state legislature to convene for a special session in Jackson. In June 1865, federal troops at Jackson arrested Clark and imprisoned him at Fort Pulaski, Georgia.

Eventually released from federal custody, Clark returned to Bolivar County, Mississippi. He quietly practiced law and served on the University of Mississippi Board of Trustees during Reconstruction. In 1876, Clark received an appointment as chancellor for the fourth judicial district. He died a year later, on December 17, 1877. Clark is buried in a family cemetery at Beulah, Mississippi.
(Wikipedia; David Sansing, “Charles Clark: Twenty-fourth Governor of Mississippi: 1863–1865,” Mississippi History Now; FindaGrave)
Charles Clark belonged to the following social groups:

person.persName: Campbell, J. A. P. (Josiah Abigail Patterson), 1830-1917
person.note:
Categories:
People -- Veterans
People -- Widowers
People -- Men

note.p: Josiah Abigail Patterson Campbell was a politician, attorney, and chief justice of the Mississippi Supreme Court during the nineteenth century.

Born on March 2, 1830, in Lancaster District, South Carolina, Campbell attended Davidson College in North Carolina and then moved to Madison County, Mississippi, around 1845. Highly intelligent, he studied law and became the youngest practicing attorney in Mississippi at the age of 17, in 1847. His legal practice thrived and he entered politics in 1851. Campbell won election to the Mississippi House of Representatives in 1851 and 1859, and served as the speaker of the house in 1859 and 1860.

When the Civil War broke out in 1861, Campbell served in the Provisional Confederate Congress and was one of the original signers of the Confederate Constitution. He then volunteered for military service, was commissioned a lieutenant colonel in the Fortieth Mississippi Infantry Regiment, and was wounded in the Second Battle of Corinth.

Following the Civil War, Campbell was elected a circuit judge, but was ejected from office by federal authorities in 1868 after refusing to swear allegiance to the United States. He strongly opposed Republican Reconstruction, and played an active part in the Mississippi Plan, which involved the use of political pressure and violence against Republicans and African Americans to reestablish conservative white, Democratic control of Mississippi. He also participated in framing the Mississippi legal codes of 1871 and 1880.

Campbell received an appointment to the Mississippi Supreme Court in 1876 and served until 1894. He was chief justice during his last three years on the court. Campbell also participated in the drafting of Mississippi’s 1890 constitution, which dismantled some of Reconstruction policies and strengthened white supremacy in the state. After leaving the Mississippi Supreme Court, Campbell returned to private law practice. He died on January 10, 1917. He was married to Eugenia Nash and had at least four children. He is buried in Greenwood Cemetery in Jackson, Mississippi.
(Wikipedia; FindaGrave)
Josiah Abigail Patterson Campbell belonged to the following social groups:
Robert Spencer Hudson was an attorney and judge in Mississippi during the nineteenth century.

Born on August 17, 1820, in Edgefield District, South Carolina, Hudson moved to Mississippi as a young man and became a leading legal figure in the state. He served as a district attorney and was a circuit judge in Mississippi during the Civil War. After the war, Hudson was prominent in efforts to restrict legal rights for African Americans, participating in Mississippi’s constitutional convention in 1865 and chairing the committee in that convention that outlined the highly discriminatory laws later known as the Black Codes. He briefly served in the Mississippi House of Representatives in 1875 and was chairman of the Committee on Impeachment during the Democratic effort to expel Republican Governor Adelbert Ames from office.

Hudson died on May 29, 1889, at the age of 68. He was married to Nancy Elvira Gray and had at least seven children that survived to adulthood. Hudson is buried in Glenwood Cemetery in Yazoo City, Mississippi.
(FindaGrave; The Clarion-Ledger, Jackson, MS, June 6, 1889)
Robert S. Hudson belonged to the following social groups:
Located in central Mississippi, Madison County was established on January 29, 1828. (Mississippi Encyclopedia; Wikipedia)

Located in Attala County, Kosciusko was located in 1834 under the name Paris and was renamed Kosciusko in 1839. Kosciusko serves as the county seat. (Wikipedia; Rowland, Mississippi, 1004; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)

gloss.p: "The processing of individuals who have committed criminal acts." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"Having officially been found guilty of a crime in a law court." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The act of putting someone in prison or the condition of being kept in prison." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The act of formally accusing someone of a serious crime." (Cambridge Dictionary)

"If someone who has committed a crime is pardoned, that person is officially forgiven and their punishment is stopped." (Cambridge Dictionary)"An act of mercy by a person in authority toward someone who has committed a crime, esp. by reducing a punishment." (Cambridge Dictionary)

"In law, a sentence is the punishment for a crime ordered by a trial court after conviction in a criminal procedure, normally at the conclusion of a trial. A sentence may consist of imprisonment, a fine, or other sanctions." (Wikipedia)
"The hearing of statements and showing of objects, etc. in a law court to judge if a person is guilty of a crime or to decide a case or a legal matter." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A person who is in charge of a trial in a court and decides how a person who is guilty of a crime should be punished, or who makes decisions on legal matters." (Cambridge Dictionary)
A person who oversees "the process of managing the property, money, etc. of someone who has died and giving it to the beneficiaries." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"Individuals responsible for enforcing laws in designated areas." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"In the U.S., an official whose job is to be in charge of performing the orders of the law courts and making certain that the laws are obeyed within a particular county." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"Someone whose job is to give advice to people about the law and speak for them in court." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A person with special training in the medical field." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A person who is trained in the preparation of medicines." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A medical doctor, especially one who has general skill and is not a surgeon." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A person who works in an office, dealing with records or performing general office duties." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A person who sells liquor." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"An official organization whose job is to manage a particular activity, suggest laws related to the activity, and make certain that laws are obeyed" concerning law enforcement. (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A place where trials and other legal cases happen, or the people present in such a place." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"In the U.S., a group of people who decide if a person who has been charged with a crime should be given a trial in a law court." (Cambridge Dictionary)
A court of law for "the legal process of deciding if a person's will has been made correctly and if the information it contains is correct." (Cambridge Dictionary)

element.value: From the Mississippi Department of Archives and History Governor Clark Collection. Petition from several citizens of Attala County, Mississippi, to Mississippi Governor Charles Clark, asking that Dr. E. H. Anderson be pardoned for allegedly illegally selling spirituous liquors.

div.p: To his Excellency Charles Clark, Governor of the State of Mississippi.

Your petitioners represent that at the March term 1865, of the Circuit Court of Attala County Dr E. H. Anderson, of Madison County, was tried on an indict-ment for selling spirituous liquor to one W. J. Young and was convicted and sentenced to three months imprisonment.

Your petitioners are assured and believe that the sale made by Dr Anderson was in good faith for medicinal purposes, that W. J. Young was and is a druggist in Kosciusko and avers that he bought the liquors for medicinal purposes:

That Dr Anderson is well known to your petitioners and is a man of high charac-ter and great respectability, whose word may be implicitly relied on and whose past life is a guaranty that he did not and would not wantonly violate the law, and your petitioners are satisfied that in this matter he has acted from a consci-entious belief that he was guilty of no wrong: We therefore respectfully pray Your Excellency to pardon Dr Anderson for the legal offence aforesaid by remitting the imprisonment prescribed in his sentence. And we will &c—

J. A. P. Campbell
John Riley Pres't Board Police
J D Sallis Probate clerk
J H Wallace Circuit Clerk
John B. Hemphill Dist Atty
Robert. S. Hudson, Judge &c
J W Scarborough Probate Judge
J. C. Lucas Dep Shff

We the undersigned Acting as Grand Jurors at the regular March term of the Circuit Court of Attalla Count having the foregoing petition presented to us take pleasure in signing the same for the purposes therein set fourth

Allen Dodd foreman
A. Malony
James L. Williams
E. M Hammond
J N Taylor
A Ricketts
A. M. Atkinson
Richd Bullock
R J Mosley
Thos Thornton
Jas A Ferguson
J W Duland
B. Westbrook
Nixon Ousley
J. M. Shumaker
E. B. Sanders
Petition for pardon of Dr E. H. Anderson
